tidySCE 0.99.1

unnest

tidyr-methods.Rd

unnest

nest

unnest(
  .data,
  cols,
  ...,
  keep_empty = FALSE,
  ptype = NULL,
  names_sep = NULL,
  names_repair = "check_unique"
)

# S3 method for default
unnest(
  .data,
  cols,
  ...,
  keep_empty = FALSE,
  ptype = NULL,
  names_sep = NULL,
  names_repair = "check_unique"
)

# S3 method for tidySCE_nested
unnest(
  .data,
  cols,
  ...,
  keep_empty = FALSE,
  ptype = NULL,
  names_sep = NULL,
  names_repair = "check_unique"
)

nest(.data, ...)

# S3 method for default
nest(.data, ...)

# S3 method for tidySCE
nest(.data, ...)

Arguments

.data

A tbl. (See tidyr)
cols

<[`tidy-select`][tidyr_tidy_select]> Columns to unnest. If you `unnest()` multiple columns, parallel entries must be of compatible sizes, i.e. they're either equal or length 1 (following the standard tidyverse recycling rules).
...

Name-variable pairs of the form new_col=c(col1, col2, col3) (See tidyr)
keep_empty

See tidyr::unnest
ptype

See tidyr::unnest
names_sep

If `NULL`, the default, the names will be left as is. In `nest()`, inner names will come from the former outer names; in `unnest()`, the new outer names will come from the inner names.

If a string, the inner and outer names will be used together. In `nest()`, the names of the new outer columns will be formed by pasting together the outer and the inner column names, separated by `names_sep`. In `unnest()`, the new inner names will have the outer names (+ `names_sep`) automatically stripped. This makes `names_sep` roughly symmetric between nesting and unnesting.
names_repair

See tidyr::unnest

Value

A tidySCE objector a tibble depending on input

A tidySCE objector a tibble depending on input

Examples


library(dplyr)
pbmc_small %>%
    tidy() %>%
    nest(data=-groups) %>%
    unnest(data)

#> # A tibble abstraction: 80 x 17
#>    cell  orig.ident nCount_RNA nFeature_RNA RNA_snn_res.0.8 letter.idents
#>    <chr> <fct>           <dbl>        <int> <fct>           <fct>        
#>  1 ATGC… SeuratPro…         70           47 0               A            
#>  2 GAAC… SeuratPro…         87           50 1               B            
#>  3 TGAC… SeuratPro…        127           56 0               A            
#>  4 AGTC… SeuratPro…        173           53 0               A            
#>  5 AGGT… SeuratPro…         62           31 0               A            
#>  6 GGGT… SeuratPro…        101           41 0               A            
#>  7 CATG… SeuratPro…         51           26 0               A            
#>  8 TACG… SeuratPro…         99           45 0               A            
#>  9 GTAA… SeuratPro…         67           33 0               A            
#> 10 TACA… SeuratPro…        109           41 0               A            
#> # … with 70 more rows, and 11 more variables: RNA_snn_res.1 <fct>, file <chr>,
#> #   ident <fct>, groups <chr>, PC_1 <dbl>, PC_2 <dbl>, PC_3 <dbl>, PC_4 <dbl>,
#> #   PC_5 <dbl>, tSNE_1 <dbl>, tSNE_2 <dbl>

library(dplyr)
pbmc_small %>%
    tidy() %>%
    nest(data=-groups) %>%
    unnest(data)

#> # A tibble abstraction: 80 x 17
#>    cell  orig.ident nCount_RNA nFeature_RNA RNA_snn_res.0.8 letter.idents
